title: How can singers sing for hours without having pain in their throat? - Quora

response.answer_text: Some of it is just endurance gained over time. It's been a while since I've had a gig, so if I were to try to go do a 4 hour show I probably wouldn't be able to finish the second set. My voice is out of shape for that, just due to lack of doing it. But I used to do 4 hour gigs once or twice a week. The tricks I used were: 1. Plan your setlist to put the most strenuous songs at the end of a set, right before a break, or barring that, make sure you have 2-3 easy (vocally) songs after a tough one. If other band members sing, let one of them sing the next song so you can rest your voice. The point is to let your voice rest right after you've pushed it hard. 2. Try not to talk on breaks. Let your voice rest, and drink water. I also liked to get away from the room, to somewhere quiet, so my ears could rest too. Being on stage is loud. 3. Be well rested before a gig. On Friday night gigs I would try to take the day off of work so I could sleep in, or at least take the afternoon off to rest (not sleep, just relax and be rested). 4. Stick to songs that fit in your comfortable range. That doesn't mean never hit a high note; use them sparingly but to good effect. Don't try to spend the whole night singing at the top of your range, you'll hurt yourself. Even a racecar can't run in the red the whole time. As for specific vocal techniques I can't really tell you what I did. I can tell when I'm straining, and sometimes I would postpone or drop a song if I thought it would be too much. If there's a high note that's hard to reach, figure out a couple easier ways to sing it, and keep them in your pocket. If you feel like you're straining too much, use one of the easier ways. Play it by ear. I promise, the crowd won't care.

They don't. We need breaks, we need a gulp of water in between, we are just normal people. Of course, singers have a trained voice, and the more you sing, the more your voice can endure over time. But in the beginning I sung two songs and my throat got sore, and now I can sing much more songs at a time. But it of course also depends on the person singing, and not every person can sing for as long as their idol can. But I found I can sing for longer times the more I sing and practise. I had the same question in mind when I started singing, but it has solved itself over time

Proper warming up technique can help you prolong the time you can sing before developing a sore throat.    You can find books on basic vocal technique for everyone from opera to pop for very reasonable prices.  Check out the line of vocal methods in Hal Leonard.  If you can afford it a teacher can be of great help in showing you the proper warm up techniques.  Unfortunately, I didn't learn this until I was in my 70's and by then had limited myself to about a 1/2 hour.  I still sing for fun, but wish I had found out about warming up earlier.

Because they relax their throats while singing & instead focus on airflow from the diaphragm.they practice singing with a relaxed throat & let the airflow control the sound.they warm up the voice with gentle vocal exercises before they sing that gradually increase in volume & pitch.they drink lots of water to lubricate the vocal cords & throat area.They make sure they don't sing outside of their range & even when they sing within their range they don't hit the really high or really low pitches for long periods of time & they regulate the volume too.

Proper vocal technique. Hydration. Proper vocal technique. Rest. Proper vocal technique. Hydration. Proper vocal technique.  A rondo of how to sing for four hours.  The correct answer is don't. Take breaks, even the linger the roles in opera (Susanna in the Marriage of Figaro and Hans Sachs in The Meistersinger) have brief respites from the stage. Wise singer cool their heels during that time and make the most of it before plunging back to the stage.

I would say from a decent guesstimate: 1. Proper warmup technique 2. Practice 3. Proper diet and awareness of needed lubrication in throat via water usually 4. Practice 5. Proper projection technique (use of diaphragm) which helps prevent over stressing the vocal chords. I wish I was actually doing all of this, but alas I am not :(
